PLC PROGRAM: 4594R4 
 
OPERATION: 
 
There are 2 sand filters. When the high level float FS-1 rises in filter 1, and remains up for B01 
minutes, solenoid valve 1 will energize for B02 minutes allowing the blower to shift from post 
aeration to scour operation. This action will loosen the particulate matter that was previously 
filtered out of the effluent water. After this time, solenoid valve 1 will de-energize. The system 
will remain off (dwell) for B03 minutes. At the end of this dwell time, clear-well pump 1 will start 
and run for B04 minutes flushing the loosened particulate matter out of the sand and into the 
mud well.  
 
After this sequence, if FS1 float does not drop back to normal, the backwash procedure will 
commence again after an off time of B01 minutes. If after a preset number of sequential 
backwashes, set in B52, the system does not reset, then an alarm will occur but the filter will 
continue with multiple backwash procedures. If no sequential backwashes occur within the time 
set in B50, then the backwash alarm will stop and counter B52 will reset. 
 
The same procedure will occur with filter 2 using its high level float FS-2, the blower, solenoid 
valve 2 and clear well pump 2. See the PLC Block Settings sheet for block numbers for filter 2. 
If the clear well level drops to the off float FS-3 level, the clear well pump will stop. It will not 
restart until the level rises to the restore float FS-4 level. This is to prevent the pumps from 
pumping dry and being damaged. Also, if the water in the clear well falls below the low level 
float, the blower will turn off until the restore float is made again. 
 
The following solenoid valve is set for on delays of the accompanying functions: 
 
B61 – Solenoid Valve 1 
B62 – Solenoid Valve 2 
 
OPTIONAL: Solenoid valve 3 continuously opens and closes periodically aerating the clear well 
based on the settings of the repeat cycle timer B09. The settings for B09 MUST remain set to 0 
for the ON and the OFF times unless Solenoid Valve 3 is utilized. 
 
The mud well pumps will operate in standard lead-lag operation. When the level rises to the 
lead float FS-6 level, the lead pump will start and pump to the off float FS-5 level. Pumps will 
alternate on each successive cycle. If when the lead pump is operating, the level continues to 
rise to the lag float FS-7 level, the lag pump will start. At this time both pumps will be operating. 
Both will pump to the off float level. If the level rises to the high level float FS-8 level, then an 
alarm will occur. 
 
The system will reset after a power outage.
